channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€How much does a Go book author make?ã€‘Go Bookä½œè€…èµšå¤šå°‘é’±ï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹549 â€” April 9, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Faster Shuffling in Go with Batching â€” Put down that deck of cards.. â€˜shufflingâ€™ here refers to moving the contents of an array about. It is based on expensive random integer generation. Here, Daniel offers up a couple of algorithms that speed things up by 2-3X compared to Goâ€™s standard Fisher-YatesÂ shuffle.

Daniel Lemire

More Predictable Benchmarking with testing.B.Loop â€” Go 1.24 introduced a new way to write benchmarks that avoids common pitfalls like accidental dead-code elimination and inaccurate timings. If you want faster, more accurate, and more intuitive benchmarking, this is forÂ you.

Junyang Shao

Does Your Postgres Database Feel Like a Black Box? â€” Are you prepared for the next high-traffic event? Join us April 16 to explore pganalyze features that tune slow queries, catch regressions, and keep Postgres running at itsÂ best.

pganalyze sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • A Go developer explains how he worked with Go and React to build his new custom blog stack.

  • ğŸ“ˆ Is Go still growing? JetBrains reflects on the results of some surveys that took place over the past year.

  • ğŸ“• Teiva Harsanyi shares the story of writing the book 100 Go Mistakes for Manning. It all started with his post The Top 10 Most Common Mistakes Iâ€™ve Seen in Go Projects which was Go Weekly's most clicked item in 2019. How much does an author make from a successful Go book? Find out here.

Life as a Go Developer on Windows â€” Go officially supports Windows as a first-class platform, but supporting a product across numerous operating systems still requires some work. For Windows that means juggling WSL quirks, file system oddities, toolchains, and platform-specificÂ code.

Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

Porting Tailscale to Plan 9 â€” A fun story from former Go core team member Brad Fitzpatrick on Tailscaleâ€™s April Foolsâ€™ Day project to port Tailscale to Bell Labsâ€™ 1980s Plan 9 OS. It was no joke, though, and actually works, despite the Go compilerâ€™s support for Plan 9 having some â€œbitrot.â€

Brad Fitzpatrick

ğŸ’° In other Tailscale news, Tailscale has just raised $160m.

ğŸ“„ Five Interesting Go Web Frameworks â€“ A quick look at Gin, Echo, Fiber, Beego and Buffalo, and their key use cases, as well as a little bonusÂ item.. Jeffrey Morhous

ğŸ“„ Goâ€™s Best-Kept Secret: Executable Examples John Arundel

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Chroma 2.16: Pure Go Syntax Highlighting â€” Take source code and turn it into syntax highlighted HTML, ANSI colored text, or just grab the raw tokens in JSON. Brings most of the features of Pygments to Go and can use Pygmentsâ€™ lexers and styles too. Thereâ€™s an online playground where you can try itÂ out.

Alec Thomas

Go Panicked Again? Yeah, Sentry Saw Itâ€”and Kept the Receipts â€” Goroutines are greatâ€”until one quietly dies. Sentry catches panics, traces them back, and gives you full context. ğŸ‘‰ Try it free before your next deploy getsÂ weird.

Sentry sponsor

GitHub MCP Server: GitHub's Official MCP Server â€” As the Model Context Protocol continues to move toward industry-standard status for giving AI agents more powers to interact with things outside their usual sandbox, GitHub has released its official server, which you can integrate with VS Code and Claude Desktop. It supports loads of tools for issues, PRs, repos, andÂ more.

GitHub

go-i18n 2.6: Translate Your Go Program Into Multiple Languages â€” A package and tool for translating Go programs into different (natural) languages. v2.6 now requires GoÂ 1.23+.

Nick Snyder

Genanki: A Go Library for Generating Anki Decks â€” Anki is a popular tool for flashcard, spaced attention styleÂ learning.

Mykyta Kysil

  • httpmock 1.4 â€“ Easy mocking of HTTP responses from externalÂ resources.

  • go-github 71.0 â€“ Go client library for accessing the GitHub APIÂ v3.

  • fsnotify 1.9 â€“ Cross-platform file system notifications inÂ Go.

  • go-ansible 2.2 â€“ Execute Ansible commands directly fromÂ Go.

  • BadgerDB 4.7 â€“ Fast Go-powered key/valueÂ database.

  • GoBGP 3.36 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€When is it OK to panic in Go?ã€‘ä»€ä¹ˆæ—¶å€™å¯ä»¥ææ…Œï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹548 â€” April 2, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

A Guide to Optimizing for High Performance in Go â€” An in-progress collection of technical articles aimed at helping Go developers write faster, more efficient apps. The initial focus is on common patterns like object pooling, struct field alignment, and using worker pools, with a guide to high-performance networking set to followÂ soon.

Alexander Stavonin

Goodbye Core Types, Hello Go As We Know and Love It â€” A look at Goâ€™s evolving type system, revealing how the abstraction of core types (introduced with generics in Go 1.18) complicated otherwise straightforward language features, and how their removal in Go 1.25 is set to simplify both the spec and everyday coding. (Hacker News reactions here.)

Robert Griesemer (Go Core Team)

2X-40X Faster Docker Builds with Blacksmith â€” With a one-line code change, Blacksmith can make your Docker builds incremental by mounting your Docker layer cache into your GitHub Actions runner. Blacksmith is used by 300+ companies like Ashby, Clerk, andÂ Mintlify.

Blacksmith sponsor

When is it OK to Panic in Go? â€” One of the Go proverbs is â€œDonâ€™t panic,â€ which isnâ€™t just good life advice but also saying not to use panic for normal error handling. Alex explores panic and some times when you should useÂ it.

Alex Edwards

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.24.2 and 1.23.8 have been released including security fixes toÂ net/http.

  • Did you know the Go gopher, as designed by RenÃ©e French, is over 25 years old? 11 years ago, Rob Pike and Andrew Gerrand told the story of Go's popular mascot on the Go blog.

  • ğŸ“ˆ The latest TIOBE index of programming language popularity is out with Go moving up from 8th to 7thÂ position.

The First Newsletter Dedicated to Product Engineers â€” Learn strategies and tactics you need to succeed as a product engineer (and build products usersÂ love).

PostHog sponsor

ğŸ“º Go Concurrency from the Beginning â€“ A nifty 8 minute video quickly touring Goâ€™s concurrency mechanisms using basicÂ examples. Living, Etc.

ğŸ“„ Building a Real-Time Notification System in Go with Postgres Ravi (Finly)

ğŸ“„ Interfacing with WebAssembly in Go David Desmarais-Michaud

ğŸ“„ Building a Network Vulnerability Scanner with Go Rez Moss (Sitepoint)

ğŸ“„ 5 GitHub Actions Every Maintainer Needs to Know Finley and Davis (GitHub)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Introducing ls-lint: A File Structure Linter â€” Billing itself as an â€˜extremely fast file and directory name linterâ€™, ls-lint is a Go powered tool for enforcing some structure over a projectâ€™s filesystem and naming policies. GitHubÂ repo.

Lucas LÃ¶ffel

urfave/cli 3.1: A Declarative Way to Build Go CLI Apps â€” The manual outlines all of the key features, but think shell auto-completion, option parsing, help text, etc.

Jeremy Saenz and Contributors

Revive 1.8: A Faster, Configurable, Flexible Linter for Go â€” A drop-in replacement of golint that aims to provide a little more structure, configurability, and performance. Itâ€™s used by numerous large Go projects and libraries. The README on the GitHub repo explains how it differs to golint.

Minko Gechev

asciigraph: ASCII Line Graph Rendering Library â€” A longstanding library for rendering basic line graphs in ASCII text, such as at the terminal, all with noÂ dependencies.

Rohit Gupta

Prefixed UUIDs: A Package That Adds Type-Safe Prefixes to UUIDs
Khaja Minhajuddin

  • DoltgreSQL 1.51 â€“ Version controlled Postgres-a-like with Git-likeÂ functionality.

  • Validator 10.26 â€“ Value validations for structs and fields based onÂ tags.

  • Buf 1.51 â€“ Tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • Clickhouse Go 2.34 â€“ Go driver forÂ ClickHouse.

  • Colly 2.2 â€“ Go scraper and crawlerÂ framework.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€How and why PlanetScale built a VM in Goã€‘Planetscaleå¦‚ä½•ä»¥åŠä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆåœ¨Goä¸­æ„å»ºäº†VM
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹547 â€” March 26, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go on the PlayStation 2 â€” If you like tinkering with consoles and shoe-horning Go into new (or old?) environments, this post is for you. It involves TinyGo, C, and a lot of trial andÂ error.

Ricardo Gomes da Silva

Make Your App an OAuth Provider â€” Use Stytch to easily add 3rd party integrations, make your app agent ready, and enable data connectivity. Be your own OAuth 2.0/OIDC Identity Provider with Stytch Connected Apps. Check out our GoÂ quickstart.

Stytch sponsor

How and Why PlanetScale Built a VM in Go â€” PlanetScale is a well known cloud based MySQL host that uses the Go-powered Vitess MySQL scaler. This article covers the tale of building a virtual machine in Go to work with the SQL ASTs produced by their SQL parser and how itâ€™s as fast (or sometimes faster) as MySQLâ€™s own C++ approach.

Vicent MartÃ­ (PlanetScale)

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“˜ If you've enjoyed Phuong Le's detailed Go blog posts recently (such as this one about unique), he has a new book out in early access called The Anatomy of Go.

  • ğŸ‚ Go version 1 was released 13 years ago this week!

  • The folks on Reddit's /r/golang got to discussing unusual or unique things they've built in Go including things like â–¶ï¸ a World of Warcraft bot, an MP3 visualizer, and code for synthesizing guitar-like sounds.

The Right Way to Do Data Fixtures in Go â€” If you donâ€™t have a strategy for data fixtures from the start, problems can show up in ways that make testing brittle. Here are some tips to get started on the right foot and prevent the need to fix your fixturesÂ later.

Brandur Leach

ğŸ”’ Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ“„ Deep vs Shallow Go Interfaces â€“ As they say, the bigger the interface, the weaker theÂ abstraction. Paschalis Tsilias

ğŸ“„ Two Mul or Not Two Mul: How I Found a 20% Improvement in ed25519 in Go Egon Elbre

ğŸ“„ How to Include Git Version Information in Go Binaries Carlana

ğŸ“„ Finding a Free Port in Go Gwendolyn

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

golangci-lint v2: A Fast Linter Runner for Go â€” A tool for running Go code linters (about 100 of them!), quickly, in parallel, with caching, YAML configuration, IDE integration, and more. There are some helpful migration instructions if youâ€™re upgrading fromÂ v1.

GolangCI Contributors

Goavatar: Generate Unique, Symmetric Identicons Based on aÂ String â€” Given a string (like a username, say), this generates very basic icons in a deterministic way that you could use for a little added visualÂ recognition.

Muhammad Saim

Physix.go: A Simple Physics Engine for Go â€” An interesting project from a high school student (who explains the background to this project here) providing basic physics capabilities when using Ebitengine.

Rudransh Bhardwaj

gocodewalker: A Way to 'Walk' Directories of Code â€” If you want to walk through a nested set of directories in a code repo while respecting .gitignore, this is forÂ you.

Ben Boyter

go-profile: A Port of Brendan Gregg's eBPF profile.py â€” eBPF opens up a way to do profiling in a faster, more direct way on Linux (details here) and this is an initial incomplete attempt to port a Python-powered eBPF profiler toÂ Go.

Ben Baker

mus-go: MUS Format Serialization Library â€” MUS is a binary serialization format focused onÂ simplicity.

Yuri Zinchenko

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Secrets are Dead: Why Machine and Workload Identities are the Future of CloudÂ Security.

Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line code change. Trusted by 250+ companies like Ashby andÂ Clerk.

  • â˜ï¸ phonenumbers 1.6 â€“ Go port of Google's libphonenumber library for parsing and validating phoneÂ numbers.

  • GoCV 0.41 â€“ Bindings for the OpenCV computer visionÂ library.

  • Freeze 0.2 â€“ Generate images of code and terminal output.

  • FrankenPHP 1.5 â€“ Modern Go-powered PHP appÂ server.

  • Gonum 0.16 â€“ A set of numeric libraries for Go.

  • Pond 2.3 â€“ Minimalistic goroutine workerÂ pool.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€Some signal boosting for Goã€‘æœ‰äº›ä¿¡å·æå‡äº†
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹550 â€” April 16, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ¥š We're taking a little break for Easter but didn't want to take the entire week off, so we have a slimline issue for you todayÂ :-) Back to full speed nextÂ Wednesday!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Using Signals with Go â€” Signals are asynchronous messages sent to processes to notify them of events like interrupts, crashes or termination, or to trigger certain behaviors. Most languages let you catch signals and act upon them, such as for shutting down a program gracefully, and Go is noÂ exception.

Jon Calhoun

Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Fuzzing Go Binaries with LibAFL â€” Built upon the Rust-powered LibAFL fuzzing library, GoLibAFL brings â€˜state-of-the-art fuzzing techniquesâ€™ to Go developers. This post compares it to existing solutions, shows off some examples, and digs into how they tailored LibAFL for Go useÂ cases.

Ollrogge and Produit

sync.Pool is Not a Silver Bullet â€” sync.Pool can reduce allocations and GC pressure, but itâ€™s not a drop-in solution for every case. Jens looks at where pooling shines (predictable, short-lived objects) and when it canÂ backfire.

Jens Neuse

Hoard of the Rings: Extracting Data From a Cheap ActivityÂ Tracker â€” Tony picked up a cheap activity tracking (heartrate, steps, etc.) ring and figured out how to use TinyGo to read its outputs. A fun yet practical use forÂ TinyGo!

Tony Smith

ğŸ“„ Most People Overlook Goâ€™s Concurrency Secrets Aryan Mehrotra

ğŸ“„ Ten Commandments of Go John Arundel

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Mockery v3: Create Mock Implementations of Interfaces â€” With the very bold claim of Mockery v3 being able to make â€œobsolete all other interface-based code generation frameworksâ€ in the Go world, the author has a good go at explaining why. If youâ€™d rather just see the facts and give it a go, the homepage is a good place toÂ start.

Landon Clipp

Bufstream: Robust Streaming for gRPC â€” Meet a cloud-first Kafka implementation custom-built for go gRPC streams. Plus, Bufstream isÂ Jepsenâ€‘tested.

Buf sponsor

Vite Backend Integration for Go â€” A way to integrate a Vite-based frontend with a Go-based backendÂ app.

Oliver Eilhard

  • Fyne 2.6 â€“ Cross platform GUI toolkit in Go. v2.6 introduces a new threading model that makes it a lotÂ faster.

  • AWS Lambda for Go 1.48 â€“ Samples & tools for Go devs building on AWSÂ Lambda.

  • pgxmock v4.7.0 â€“ Simulate pgx behavior in tests without a real DBÂ connection.

  • go-git v5.16.0 â€“ Extensible Git implementation written in pure Go.

  • Revive 1.9 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • Mongo DB Driver 2.2 â€“ The official Go driver forÂ MongoDB.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of some other interesting updates or useful resources in the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • Miguel Young de la Sota explains what a 'target triple' is (those things that look like x86_64-unknown-linux and explain what architecture and OS a binary is targeting). Go gets a big mention due to its native support for cross compiling, but the author isn't particularly impressed with Go's approach toÂ targeting.

  • The MITRE-managed Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) program is coming to an end this month due to a cut in DHS funding. However, The CVE Foundation has been rapidly created to carry on its essential cybersecurityÂ work.

  • ğŸ“˜ Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has released Exploring TypeScript: TS 5.8 Edition â€“ you can buy it, but also read it all online for free in HTML form.

  • ğŸ¤– Last week, Google unveiled Firebase Studio, an online agentic AI development environment somewhat akin to things you might have seen from v0, Cursor orÂ Lovable.

  • I rarely need to work with modern graphics or Web design techniques, but this look at creating a flowing WebGL gradient is a fascinating breakdown of using math and modern Web technologies to create a plasmaÂ effect.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>
unsub |Â Â  Webç‰ˆæœ¬

ğŸ¥š We're taking a little break for Easter but didn't want to take the entire week off, so we have a slimline issue for you todayÂ :-) Back to full speed nextÂ Wednesday!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor
